title-group.article-title: Comparative Analysis of Adipose-Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cells Isolated From Abdominal and Breast Tissue

article-meta.aff: University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, Wisconsin

author-notes.corresp: Dr Summer E. Hanson, Division of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, G5/361 CSC, 600 Highland Ave, Madison, WI 53792, USA. E-mail: shanson.mdphd@gmail.com

fn.p: This work was presented in part at The Aesthetic Meeting 2012 and received the Gaspar W. Anastasi Award at the Resident and Fellows Forum. This manuscript also received the 2012 Aesthetic Surgery Journal award for Best Resident Paper in the Research division.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 The American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery, Inc.
permissions.copyright-holder: American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery, Inc.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ADSC) may have a potential dual role in soft tissue augmentation by suppressing inflammation and promoting regeneration. Due to these properties, there is increasing interest in their potential use in autologous fat grafting, particularly to the breast.

sec.title: Objectives:
sec.p: The authors isolate and compare ADSC derived from abdominal and breast tissues with a hypothesis that different adipose tissue sources may demonstrate different functional characteristics affecting outcomes in autologous cell transplantation in reconstructive and aesthetic surgery.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells from abdominal and breast tissues were isolated and compared in terms of surface marker expression, differentiation capabilities, and both fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and receptor expression. Immunophenotype of macrophages was also investigated using cell surface markers following a 7-day co-culture period with ADSC.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Results showed similar cell surface phenotype and multilineage differentiation capabilities of ADSC derived from abdominal and breast tissues. Variations of FGF expression were demonstrated on reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, with a significantly higher expression of FGF2 seen in breast ADSC. Following the 7-day co-culture period, increased expression of the anti-inflammatory surface marker CD206 was identified, with decreased CD16 and human leukocyte antigen–DR on macrophages co-cultured with ADSC compared with controls.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: The data indicate similarities between ADSC derived from abdominal and breast tissues. Significant differences were seen, however, in the expression of FGF2, which is important in angiogenesis and wound healing. The results support the utility of ADSC in cell-based therapies such as autologous fat grafting.

body.p: Fat grafting for breast augmentation or reconstruction has received much attention over the past few decades, but the safety and efficacy of autologous fat transfer continue to be debated. Among the concerns are the inflammatory response that may lead to fat necrosis, microcalcifications, and cyst formation.1 Additionally, transferred tissue is susceptible to mechanical damage during harvest, limited revascularization, and donor site morbidity. While the fate of the grafted fat has not been fully elucidated, its clinical utility has expanded over the past several years.2,3 Of recent interest is the addition of undifferentiated adipose tissue–derived mesenchymal stem cells (ADSC) to improve graft survival.4

Originally isolated from the bone marrow stroma, mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) provide structural and physiological support for bone marrow hematopoietic cells and, furthermore, are capable of differentiating into fat, bone, and cartilage.5 Although first isolated around the same time as bone marrow MSC, adipose-derived progenitor cells derived from the stromal vascular fraction (SVF) were not identified as MSC until years later.6 It is now assumed that MSC in general provide microenvironmental stromal support for their tissue of residence, and in fat tissue, it is also assumed that MSC are progenitors of adipocytes.7 Thus, ADSC could play a significant role in plastic surgery and tissue engineering by providing a novel source of self-renewing cells for soft tissue reconstruction or augmentation, in addition to their many other favorable regenerative roles.8,9 Adipose-derived MSC are easily harvested, mechanically stable, readily expanded in cell culture, and used in clinical applications similar to their bone marrow–derived counterpart.

There is mounting evidence that in addition to transdifferentiation, MSC have unique immunomodulatory properties as well. A variety of in vitro studies with bone marrow–derived MSC have shown that they possess the ability to suppress activation and proliferation of immune cells such as T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, natural killer (NK) cells, and dendritic cells.10 Our interest is in the effect of MSC on macrophages, given their role in tissue healing and inflammation. Classically activated macrophages are associated with proinflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF)–α, interleukin (IL)–1β, and interferon (IFN)–γ, all of which recruit additional inflammatory cells to the site of tissue injury. Alternatively activated macrophages characteristically demonstrate IL-10, which has been shown to downregulate inflammation and, in some autoimmune disorders, is a marker of resolution of pathology. Recent evidence indicates that there is a spectrum of macrophage activation with variations in surface marker expression, cytokine production, and downstream effect on inflammation, which could serve as a therapeutic target in many applications in reconstructive surgery.

We have recently shown that co-culture of human bone marrow–derived MSC with peripheral blood monocytes results in a phenotypically anti-inflammatory macrophage with unique functional characteristics. These MSC-educated macrophages (MEM) demonstrate higher expression of CD206 and IL-10 with decreased TNF-α, as well as increased phagocytic activity, compared with macrophages cultured in isolation.11 Taken together, this combination indicates a distinct alternative activation. The goal of this study was 2-fold. The first step was to characterize MSC isolated from both abdominal and breast adipose tissues given their utility in reconstruction and fat grafting. In addition to markers used to define MSC, we examined expression of fibroblast growth factors (FGF). Second, we wanted to explore the interaction between breast and abdominal AMSC when co-cultured with differentiating macrophages. We hypothesized that MSC isolated from different adipose tissue sources—breast and abdominal tissues—may demonstrate different functional characteristics in vitro, both in isolation and when co-cultured with allogeneic monocyte-derived macrophages. To our knowledge, there are no studies investigating the specific interaction between adipose tissue–derived MSC and macrophages, particularly those comparing abdominal fat with breast fat. We propose that these differences could contribute to the inflammation or fibrosis that may be seen following implantation of autologous fat grafts into breast tissue, and furthermore, the differences may have implications in tissue engineering strategies.

sec.title: Derivation of Mesenchymal Stem Cells and Macrophages
sec.p: All protocols to collect tissue samples were approved by the University of Wisconsin Institutional Review Board. Adipose tissue was harvested from normal healthy patients undergoing elective cosmetic surgery, either abdominoplasty (abdominal MSC) or reduction mammaplasty (breast MSC). Mesenchymal stem cells were isolated as previously described.12 Briefly, the excised adipose tissue was rinsed with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), minced, and digested with collagenase/PBS (Sigma, St Louis, Missouri) at 37°C for 45 minutes. The sample was neutralized with an equal volume of media and centrifuged at 1200 rpm for 5 minutes. Red blood cells (RBC) were lysed with 3-minute incubations in RBC lysis buffer, and mononuclear cells were suspended in supplemented alpha minimum essential media (α-MEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS; Hyclone, Logan, Utah), 1× nonessential amino acids (NEAA; Sigma), 4 mM L-glutamine (Sigma), and 100 U/mL penicillin, 0.01 mg/mL streptomycin sulfate (Sigma). After adherence of stromal cells to plastic plates, the culture media were changed to remove nonadherent cells. The cells were cultured in a 37°C incubator with 5% CO2/95% humidified atmosphere. Media were changed every 3 days, and the cells were expanded until passages 4 to 6, at which time they were used for flow cytometry, differentiation experiments, and co-culture studies.

Macrophages from different donors were derived from peripheral blood monocytes of unrelated donors as described previously11 and used in co-culture experiments. Buffy coat samples were obtained from normal healthy donors (Interstate Blood Bank, Memphis, Tennessee) and mononuclear cells isolated by density grade centrifugation. Mononuclear cells were then incubated with anti–human CD14 microbeads (Miltenyi Biotech, Auburn, California) for 15 minutes at 4°C and washed to remove unbound antibody. A pure population of CD14+ cells was collected using an AutoMACS Pro Separator (Miltenyi Biotech) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The markers used to distinguish macrophages and dendritic cells are controversial, and there may be overlap; however, CD14 and CD163 are used to identify activated macrophages, with CD209 being characteristic of dendritic cells. This method has been shown to yield >95% CD14+ with uniformly CD209–cell purity via flow cytometry in our laboratory.11

sec.title: Fluorescent-Activated Cell Sorting Analysis
sec.p: Following culture expansion to P4, cells were removed from the tissue culture polystyrene flasks via trypsinization (TrypLE; Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California). Resulting cell suspensions were incubated with 10 µL of Fc Receptor Blocking Agent (Miltenyi Biotech) in the dark for 15 minutes at 4°C. Surface antibodies were then added and incubated for 30 minutes at 4°C in the dark. Antibodies used were monoclonal mouse fluorescently labeled, specific to human, as follows: anti-CD14 allophycocyanin (APC), anti-CD31 APC, anti-CD45 phycoerythrin (PE), anti-CD90 peridinin chlorophyll protein (PerCP-Cy5.5), anti-CD105 APC (all eBioscience, San Diego, California), anti-CD14 fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC), anti-CD29 PE, anti-CD34 FITC, anti-CD44 PE, anti-CD73 PE, and anti-CD90 APC (all BD Pharmingen, San Diego, California). The cells were washed with autoMACS separation buffer (PBS), 2 mM EDTA, 0.5% bovine serum albumin, pH 7.2 (Miltenyi Biotech), and fixed with 1% paraformaldehyde in PBS until ready for analysis within 24 hours. Control staining with directly labeled, isotype-matched monoclonal antibodies was included in all fluorescent-activated cell sorting (FACS) experiments. Data were acquired by using an Accuri C6 flow cytometer (Accuri, Ann Arbor, Michigan) and analyzed by using CFlow software (Accuri).

sec.title: Differentiation of Cells Toward Osteogenic, Adipogenic, or Chondrogenic Lineages
sec.p: Cell differentiation into osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic lineages and subsequent detection were performed using established methodologies.12 Briefly, MSC were treated with osteogenic, adipogenic, or chondrogenic medium (Miltenyi Biotech) for up to 21 days, with media changes every 3 to 4 days. Cultures were assayed for mineral content by Alizarin red S staining (Acros Organics, Newark, New Jersey) and for lipid accumulation by Oil Red O staining (Sigma). Controls included cells treated with standard culture media and stained per protocol.

sec.title: Co-culture
sec.p: Once MSC were expanded to passage 4, they were plated in 6-well polystyrene plates at a concentration of 200 000 cells/well. Within 2 hours of plating the MSC, isolated CD14+ cells (1 × 106 cells) were thawed, washed with PBS, and added to the surface of the plates. Cells were cultured in phenol red free RPMI-1640 supplemented with 10% FBS, 2 mM L-glutamine, 1% sodium pyruvate, and 1% NEAA for 7 days. The plates were kept in a 37°C incubator with 5% CO2/95% humidified atmosphere for a total of 7 days. Following a 7-day culture, media (including nonadherent cells) were aspirated from each well. The adherent macrophages and MSC were harvested from the polystyrene surface using a cell scraper. The resulting macrophage suspensions were used for FACS analysis immediately.

sec.title: Quantitative Reverse-Transcriptase Polymerase Chain Reaction Assay
sec.p: RNA isolation and complementary DNA synthesis were performed as previously described.11 Power SYBR green master mix (Applied Biosystems, Carlsbad, California) and verified primers purchased from Qiagen (Germantown, Maryland) were used for reaction. The threshold cycle (Ct) value for each gene was normalized by subtracting the average Ct number of 3 housekeeping genes (RN18S1, GAPDH, and ACTB).

sec.title: MSC Characterization
sec.p: Mesenchymal stem cells were harvested from abdominal and breast adipose tissues and expanded to passages 4 to 6 (Figure 1). Cells were positive for MSC markers such as CD29, CD73, CD90, and CD105 and negative for hematopoietic markers such as CD14, CD31, CD34, and CD45 (Figure 2). Mesenchymal stem cells subjected to osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic culture conditions were shown to differentiate along their respective lineages after 14 to 21 days in culture. Alizarin red S staining showed deposits of calcium crystals stained orange to brown, Oil Red O staining showed lipid vacuoles stained red, and Safronin O demonstrated glycosaminoglycan stained frothy pink (Figure 1), verifying these cells’ identity as MSC according to the accepted criteria.5

caption.p: Morphology and differentiation of adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells. Representative microscopic views of human adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ADSC) from abdominal tissue (A-D) and breast tissue (E-H). Undifferentiated cells (5× magnification) demonstrate spindle shape and adherence to polystyrene (A, E). Assays demonstrate that both abdominal and breast ADSC were capable of differentiation along osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic lineages (20× magnification). Alizarin red S staining shows deposits of calcium crystals stained orange to brown (B, F), Oil Red O staining shows lipid vacuoles stained red (C, G), and Safranin O staining shows cartilage-specific glycosaminoglycans (D, H).

Phenotype of abdominal mesenchymal stem cells from abdominal and breast tissues. Representative fluorescent-activated cell sorting analysis of abdominal (A-I) and breast (J-R) adipose-derived stem cells for different cell surface markers. The cells were uniformly positive for mesenchymal markers CD29, CD44, CD73, CD90, and CD105; in addition, the cells were negative for hematopoietic and endothelial markers CD14, CD31, CD34, and CD45.

sec.title: Comparison of FGF Expression Between Breast and Abdominal Adipose Tissue–Derived MSC
sec.p: Real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis showed that FGF3 and FGF6 expression levels were significantly higher in abdominal adipose MSC compared with breast adipose MSC (fold difference 15.2 vs 12.3 and 16.4 vs 13.3, P < .05), while FGF2 and FGF9 expression was higher in the breast tissue–derived cells (fold difference 5.18 vs 2.57 and 14.2 vs 8.37, P < .05; Figure 3). Other genes tested, including FGF receptors, were not expressed at statistically significant different levels between abdominal adipose MSC and breast adipose MSC.

caption.p: The expression of FGF and FGFR in adipose-derived stem cells derived from abdominal and breast adipose tissues. Data are shown as mean fold increase ± standard deviation. Statistical significance is shown as *P < .05. Real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis showed that FGF3 and FGF6 expression levels were significantly higher in abdominal adipose mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) compared with breast adipose MSC (fold difference 15.2 vs 12.3 and 16.4 vs 13.3, *P < .05), while FGF2 and FGF9 expression was higher in the breast tissue–derived cells (fold difference 5.18 vs 2.57 and 14.2 vs 8.37, *P < .05). Other genes tested, including FGFR, were not expressed at statistically significant different levels between abdominal adipose MSC and breast adipose MSC.

sec.title: Comparison of Macrophages Co-cultured With Breast or Abdominal Adipose MSC
sec.p: Macrophage phenotype can be an indicator of their primary role in physiological processes such as inflammation and tissue healing. The expression of such surface markers important to inflammation and wound healing in macrophages after their co-culture with breast or abdominal adipose tissue–derived MSC was studied using FACS analysis. Figures 4 and 5 show representative plots of experiments performed in triplicate. Macrophages cultured alone were used as control for comparison.

caption.p: Anti-inflammatory surface marker expression of CD14+ monocyte-derived macrophages co-cultured with abdominal mesenchymal stem cells. Following a 7-day co-culture period, CD14+ macrophages were isolated and stained for CD206 (y-axis) and CD163 (x-axis). Markers of macrophages cultured on polystyrene control plates are shown in A. Macrophages co-cultured with abdominal adipose-derived stem cells (ADSC) are shown in B. Macrophages co-cultured with breast ADSC are shown in C. There was significantly lower expression of CD206 on control macrophages compared with the experimental groups (P < .05). There was no difference between those cultured with abdominal ADSC compared with breast ADSC (control macrophages 8.47%, with abdominal ADSC 91.0% and with breast ADSC 85.8%). There was similar, low expression of CD163 compared with macrophages cultured alone (control macrophages 0.13%, with abdominal ADSC 0.58% and with breast ADSC 1.23%).

Proinflammatory surface marker expression of CD14+ monocyte-derived macrophages co-cultured with abdominal mesenchymal stem cells (AMSC). Following a 7-day co-culture period, CD14+ macrophages were isolated and stained for human leukocyte antigen (HLA)–DR (y-axis) and CD16 (y-axis). Markers of macrophages cultured on polystyrene control plates are shown in A. Macrophages co-cultured with abdominal AMSC are shown in B. Macrophages co-cultured with breast AMSC are shown in C. There was significantly higher expression of HLA-DR on macrophages cultured alone compared with those cultured with adipose-derived stem cells (ADSC) (P < .05; control macrophages 90.1%, with abdominal ADSC 25.2% and with breast ADSC 30.6%). A similar expression pattern was seen in CD16 (P < .05; control macrophages 91.6%, with abdominal ADSC 14.2% and with breast ADSC 20.4%). There were no differences between abdominal and breast tissue sources.

sec.p: Macrophages co-cultured with adipose tissue–derived MSC demonstrated greater expression of CD206, an anti-inflammatory marker, compared with macrophages cultured alone (P < .05). There was no difference between those cultured with abdominal ADSC compared with breast ADSC (control macrophages 8.47%, with abdominal ADSC 91% and with breast ADSC 85.8%). There was similar, low expression of CD163, an indicator of classical macrophage activation, compared with macrophages cultured alone (Figure 4; control macrophages 0.13%, with abdominal ADSC 0.58% and with breast ADSC 1.23%). Human leukocyte antigen (HLA)–DR is a major histocompatibility complex class II surface molecule involved in T-lymphocyte activation and proinflammatory pathways. Additionally, CD16 is upregulated on CD14+ macrophages in acute inflammation. Following the 7-day co-culture, we found significantly higher expression of HLA-DR on macrophages cultured alone compared with those cultured with ADSC (control macrophages 90.1%, with abdominal ADSC 25.2% and with breast ADSC 30.6%). A similar expression pattern was seen in CD16 (control macrophages 91.6%, with abdominal ADSC 14.2% and with breast ADSC 20.4%). There was essentially no expression of CD209, an indicator of dendritic cell phenotype (data not shown).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Autologous fat grafting has been used for more than a century in reconstructing soft tissue defects, since it was first described by Nueber in 1893.3 The popularity of fat grafting has waxed and waned over the past few decades. With advances in surgical techniques to harvest and process the tissue to be grafted, autologous fat transfer has again gained interest, particularly to address breast reconstruction, asymmetry, and augmentation.13-15 The physiological environment of breast adipose tissue is unlike any other subcutaneous or white fat in the body, such as the abdomen, given the close proximity to the mammary epithelial tissue. Here, adipocytes actively participate in the development of the mammary gland. For instance, lactation is characterized by rapid lipolysis and decreased adipocyte volume, while involution allows for lipid filling and expansion, largely due to bidirectional interaction between epithelial cells and adipocytes in the adjacent SVF. Likewise, it is thought that MSC may be functionally different based on their tissue origin.16 While this difference may not be clinically relevant for some disorders, both the direct contact and paracrine effects of ADSC transferred from one tissue source to another, as in reconstructive surgery, warrant further investigation. To this end, we identified and compared AMSC from abdominal and breast tissue, looking at defining criteria as well as early markers of inflammation and healing.

Whether a simple wound or complex tissue transfer, inflammation and regeneration are highly integrated processes coordinated by a variety of cells, cytokines, and growth factors, with the end result often being fibrosis or scar. Fibroblast growth factors are key mediators in wound healing.17 In general, this family of proteins is associated with endothelial cell and fibroblast migration and proliferation. They are thought to be responsible, in part, for angiogenesis associated with wound healing as well as granulation tissue formation. In vivo models of FGF application to wounded tissue demonstrate enhanced vascularization and re-epithelialization. Each member of the FGF family has a slightly different functional role; these proteins are often expressed differentially in most tissues, and their timing and patterns are variable. Interestingly, we found variations in expression of FGF between ADSC from abdominal and breast tissue with no differences in receptor expression. In particular, we demonstrated increased expression in FGF2 and FGF9 in ADSC derived from breast tissue and increased expression of FGF3 and FGF6 in AMSC derived from abdominal tissue. FGF3 is commonly associated with embryonic development and bone growth, and it is expressed at low levels in adult tissues, while FGF6 has been associated with higher expression in myogenic lineages. These findings may indicate a role for abdominal ADSC in skeletal muscle or bone regeneration in tissue engineering applications, in addition to soft tissue applications.

Breast ADSC showed higher expression of FGF2 compared with abdominal ADSC. FGF2 is highly involved in angiogenesis and collagen deposition and remodeling. Animal studies have demonstrated an increase in type I collagen stability associated with FGF2, while in the absence of FGF, the normal phenotypic expression of collagen is altered, with a loss of polarity and growth pattern.18 It is unknown how the differences observed in this in vitro model will translate clinically, specifically in autologous fat grafting. Augmented fibroblast proliferation and collagen deposition may lead to late fibrosis or thickening of the tissue disrupted by fat graft deposition. Alternatively, angiogenesis and neovascularization seen in wound healing models may lead to new vessel ingrowth to the transferred fat and reduce tissue ischemia or improve graft take. The exact fate of locally or systemically delivered ADSC has not been clearly established,19,20 and it is easy to imagine ADSC-augmented tissue can be subject to either scenario. Additionally, the functional aspects of breast-derived ADSC are not as well studied as their abdominal or bone marrow counterparts. The question of which cell source will be more favorable in clinical use is important since cell-based therapies are rapidly expanding. For this reason, ADSC from abdominal tissues, harvested through lipoaspirate or excision, will be more likely to be clinically useful.

Our group has previously shown differential expression of pro- or anti-inflammatory markers of macrophage activation following culture with bone marrow–derived MSC, indicating an anti-inflammatory effect.11,21 In this study, we demonstrated a similar effect when co-cultured with ADSC, with no statistical difference between abdominal and breast adipose tissues. Clinically, both CD16 and HLA-DR are measures of acute inflammation, particularly in systemic disease and trauma; reduction in these markers on circulating macrophages may be an indication in the resolution of inflammation. There may also be an association with other acute phase proteins such as TNF-α, IL-1β, and IFN-γ.11 It has yet to be determined how data such as this, which demonstrate immunomodulatory and regenerative properties of ADSC, will translate clinically. Additionally, the engraftment or “take” of AMSC has been shown to be variable, potentially limiting the anti-inflammatory or regenerative effect.22 However, as these cells are rapidly expanding to clinical trials and are also of interest in fat grafting, in vitro studies, like the current work, offer a controlled environment to explore cellular and molecular interactions and warrant further investigation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: These data, taken together with the ease of isolation and culture expansion of ADSC, further support a role of abdominal adipose tissue derived in cell-based therapies and tissue engineering for their multipotent, immunoregulatory, and regenerative properties.

The results of this study demonstrate similarities in ADSC derived from adipose tissues of the breast and abdomen. These cells reliably express surface markers and multipotency characteristics of typical MSC. When co-cultured with macrophages, these cells do not promote an inflammatory phenotype; instead, we offer evidence of an alternative or MSC-educated macrophage phenotype, consistent with our work previously shown in bone marrow–derived MSC. Furthermore, the expression of several fibroblast growth factors and FGF receptors is similar between AMSC from breast and abdominal tissues. Emerging translational and clinical data on the addition of autologous progenitor cells to adipose tissue show promise for improved results, although long-term studies are necessary.

fn.label: Disclosures
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was funded in part by the Aesthetic Surgery Education and Research Foundation (ASERF) grant (S.E.H.) and in part by Department of Defense Concept Award (W81XWH-09-1-0532, P.H.).
